body: Ben, the test failure looks related to the patch. Can you check?

oh wow, thanks for all the corrections. Must be serious effort. 

Just one little correction that should be reverted (see comment above) and I'll be happy to merge.

Can we change the third type parameter of KWindowedTable (= W) to Window instead of WindowDef
and also the type parameter of WindowDef to Window?

`KWindowedTable<K, V, W extends Window>`
`WindowDef<W extends Window>`
LGTM. @hachikuji do you want to change the logging level before merging. Also a good idea to strengthen system tests for this case.

@ymatsuda About `KWindowedTable` I think we have to use `WindowDef` here since `Window` only represents a single window instance while the table itself could represent all the windows it currently contain.

About `WindowDef` yeah I agree we can make it that way: I used to make `Window` an abstract class but did not find any use customized `Window` object so I changed it back to a normal class.
Why can't we make the type parameter W of `KWindowedTable` be `Window`? With my suggested changes, aggregateByKey can have a parameter of `WindowDef<W>`.
LGTM. Merged to trunk.

@guozhangwang I don't understand the reasoning for setting `MAX_BLOCK_MS_CONFIG` to `Long.MaxValue` by default. Doesn't this mean that the test suite could hang instead of failing after a time out in case of bugs? Wouldn't it be better to set a time out that is high enough for our tests, but much lower than `Long.MaxValue`? Maybe 1 minute or something along those lines?

@gwenshap indeed it did! Thanks :) 
@granders as discussed take a quick look at this PR where I changed a few aspects of the produce_consume_validate class. I'll run the branchbuilder run once all feedback is in.
@vahidhashemian will you have time to correct my comment above?
LGTM, but will wait for @granders to take a look too.
@gwenshap yes, I'll try to get to it today. sorry for the delay.

@guozhangwang I reduced the logging to trace level along the "happy paths." The build failure looks like an instance of KAFKA-2442. I can make the changes to the system tests here, but would that make cherry-picking more difficult for the 0.9.0 branch?
IMO system tests could be done as a separate JIRA since this branch was validated by the reporter of this issue.
@hachikuji did you run the system tests on this branch? If not, maybe a good idea to do it?
Will create a new pull request.
@benstopford Thanks for these improvements. I suggested a few tweaks, but this looks good

Can we make Window an abstract class? Since a hopping window and a sliding window should not be comparable, each windowing scheme should implement own window class. And KWindowedTable should be typed with the window type through generics.

Does it has any functionality impact?
Which release version is the change included?
@ijuma Yeah you are right. Setting it to MaxValue is not a good solution actually. I will submit a follow-up patch shortly.
@ijuma I haven't run all system tests, but I've run consumer_test.py a couple times without problems.
FYI: I created KAFKA-2989 to improve the system tests.

@StarWindMoonCloud It is included in the latest 0.9.0.0 release. It should not have any functionality impact: its previous behavior is incorrect of always using its latest version, while the right behavior should be using the version of the request. The only request version bump is introduced in 0.9.0.0.
Merged to trunk and 0.9.0.
Ping @ijuma for reviews.
LGTM
Thanks for catching and fixing.
LGTM

In my opinion, this is not a bug. There is no guarantee that compiling with 1.8 will work when executed with 1.7. Having said that, it's a tiny change and could be justified on its own merits (ie expose the interface, not the implementation). So LGTM.
LGTM
Can you fix the PR title though? There is no cast in your code, just a type annotation (casts are unsafe, type annotation are not).
@ijuma I saw these errors when running ducktape tests, so if we're not supporting it, then we should make sure that ducktape vms use 1.8 jdk when running tests.
@hachikuji, you're supposed  to compile Kafka with Java 7 (and you can run with both 7 and 8, 8 recommended).
@EamonZhang Any reason this was closed? I think it should get pulled in.
@ymatsuda Ping for another look.

@hachikuji @ijuma This is something that we check in `build.sh` in muckrake, but which I don't think is validated anywhere for kafka tests because we just assume the version built in the checked out copy will work, but the VMs install JDK7.

We should probably add validation of of the build version of java somewhere. I think 7/8 issues have happened a few times. I just always stick to the minimum Java version supported, which also prevents accidental use of newer libraries during development, but I know not everyone likes doing that. Another option is building separately within each VM, but that's annoyingly expensive. Beyond having some preflight check for tests to check java version, I'm not sure there's a great solution.
Merged to trunk.
@granthenke  Sorry for misoperation
Adding a check sounds good to me. I think people often don't do it because they're not aware that it can cause issues.

If Java 7 is needed to build, then we should document that requirement. We also have checks in the gradle file which are specific to Java 8 (doclint in particular), so it's not unreasonable for users to assume it's supported.
Making create topic blocking will be useful, but is also a bit tricky. We have to wait until the topic metadata is propagated to all brokers.
LGTM
@becketqin I am a little confused that "thread blocks when trying to stop the fetchers", since the ConsumerFetcherThread is set to be interruptable, so shutting down should not be blocked?

@Gueust I see, that's a fair point but I did not took time to test those scripts on `sh` instead of `bash`.

I think that could be addressed in a different PR if needed.
Review by @ewencp and @hachikuji
Review by @gwenshap
Full build running here: http://jenkins.confluent.io/job/kafka_system_tests_branch_builder/327/
@ewencp Would you have a change to review again?
@Parth-Brahmbhatt I think we should use the principal builder as we proposed it as the way to construct a principal incase of SSL and it will be consistent across the SSL and SASL.
The new patch is available at https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/673.

@junrao @granthenke In TestUtils we have a set of functions like `waitUntilXXX` and one of them checks the metadata has been propagated, maybe we can do similar things here (of course we cannot access the metadata caches directly, but through metadata request from the controller).

@hachikuji Filed https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/677 for the documentation side. Regarding the Java 8 doclint code in Gradle, we do have a Java 8 build in Jenkins, but it both compiles and runs with Java 8 (this helps ensure that our code also compiles with Java 8 making it easy to move to that version when the time comes).

By the way, this will no longer be an issue when Java 9 is released in 2017:

http://openjdk.java.net/jeps/247

;)
LGTM.

@guozhangwang @junrao I was starting to look into something along those lines, and will have more time later this week. A big question is whether we want to do the (optional) polling/blocking on the broker side before we respond or on the client side. What advantages do we get from doing it client side or broker side?
LGTM

@ZoneMayor It's good that the scripts are setting the actual classpath. However, there is quite a bit of duplication. Would it be possible to extract some of this code to another shell script that would then be sourced in order to avoid duplication?
LGTM
Thank you for your contribution.
LGTM

@benstopford Can you double check the system test failures? They look like they may be related? 
http://jenkins.confluent.io/job/kafka_system_tests_branch_builder/327/
@ymatsuda Addressed comments.

Thanks for the contribution! Interesting, I'd think that Scala's lazy eval would be enough here, but I'm obviously missing something...

Can you open a ticket and maybe add the profiler results before / after?
@gwenshap The objects in question are the closures that enable the lazy eval there. I'm happy to make a ticket, but unfortunately the YourKit license I used to do this profiling has expired.
@rajinisivaram Thanks for the update. I left a couple nitpick comments, but overall this seems a lot clearer.
LGTM.
LGTM
LGTM
Thanks for contributing @ckolbeck !
Thanks a bunch, @gwenshap and @ijuma
LGTM too; merging since it looks like @guozhangwang has not yet.

@granthenke Sorry for the further compatibility comments, but I'm particularly worried about changes like these because I don't think we have a good way to catch them aside from manual inspection -- even compatibility system tests would need to be careful to exercise the functionality since I think it won't cause simple errors, just seemingly weird behavior where code that previously caught all exceptions that could be thrown will no longer catch the exceptions being thrown by the newer version's implementation.
@hachikuji Thank you for the reviews. Have made the changes.
@fpj Do you have time to review this?
@ijuma will do, thanks for the heads up.
@ewencp Is there any reason why we should not do this?
Does this cause a large number of deprecation warnings when we build Kafka?
./gradlew test passed locally

@ijuma I can't think of a reason not to especially since we already do it with the `validate` method and I agree it's a lot cleaner to avoid all those casts. It seems like we're also missing the `@Override` annotation which helps check the validity of changes like this.

@ewencp No need to apologize. These things are important. I appreciate the actionable reviews. 

I have updated the patch to removed all deprecations and hierarchy breaking changes. This is now only a migration of the server side usage of Errors.java. Cleanup of duplicate Exceptions and Mappings will be at a later date in a later patch.
Thanks @ewencp. Good point about `@Override`, I pushed an additional commit that adds the annotation to the overridden methods in `Schema`.

@granthenke I haven't checked the code, but I think migrating the server side usage is the way forward. In terms of deprecating `ErrorMappings`, I think we should only do that when we deprecate the old consumers.
@ijuma There are no deprecations in this change.
@granthenke I know. :) Maybe I wasn't clear, but I was saying that I agree with those changes being done later and I was suggesting when I thought it would be appropriate to do them.
@ijuma Ah, cool. Agreed. :)
@ymatsuda Modified built-in aggregates.

Thanks @ZoneMayor, this makes sense to me. However in terms of the fix could we make MinCleanableDirtyRatioProp configurable in makeCleaner and set it to 0 in testCleaner so that it will always trigger cleaning regardless of the ratio?

@ewencp Hi Ewen, sorry for the delay*, closing now. Thanks for cherry-picking!
- I have been absent of Kafka project for some time now, coming back again :)
LGTM. Jenkins failures are not relevant.
@ymatsuda Comments addressed.

@guozhangwang , the problem is that the fetchers are not guaranteed to be in blocked state when the shutdown() is called on them. It seems calling interrupt on a running thread does not have any effect but set the interrupted flag. So if the interrupt() call happen before they are blocked on enqueue(), the fetchers will still get blocked.

@becketqin Hmm, I think that if the interrupt status flag is set, then upon `enqueue` which calls `BlockingQueue.put`, it will throw InterruptedException directly since it calls `ReentrantLock.lockInterruptibly`, which will still throw InterruptedException according to Javadoc?

"If the current thread:

has its interrupted status set on entry to this method; or
is interrupted while acquiring the lock,
then InterruptedException is thrown and the current thread's interrupted status is cleared."

@guozhangwang That is a good point. However the stack trace showed the Abstract fetcher thread was not interrupted, somehow. My best guess is that after the first round of rebalance finishes, before the fetcher threads actually started, the second round of rebalance was trying to call `interrupt()` on the threads and shutdown them. In that case, the `interrupt()` will have no effect because the fetcher threads haven't started yet.
It's been a while, PR which was passing the build before no longer merges with master without conflict, maybe it's no longer relevant even; needs to be checked and rebased if still relevant.
We probably should mention this in the upgrade notes.
LGTM
@guozhangwang  already removed the semicolons
